channel.title: BBC News - Europe

item.title: Spain fire: Thousands flee blaze near Costa del Sol town
item.description: Almost 2,000 people have left their homes as the military joins efforts to contain the flames.

item.title: Pope’s Slovakia visit sends signal after brief Hungary stop
item.description: The first papal visit in 18 years produces pleasure and puzzlement after a brief stop in Hungary.

item.title: German election: Hunger strikers want greater action on climate change
item.description: Six young people say they won't end their hunger strike until the leading candidates meet them.

item.title: Eitan Biran: Italy investigates 'kidnap' of cable car crash survivor
item.description: The grandfather accused of whisking his grandson to Israel is placed under investigation in Italy.

item.title: Arc de Triomphe wrapped in fabric in tribute to artist
item.description: Crowds gather to see the monument draped in plastic for an project inspired by late artist Christo.

item.title: French slave statue defaced in apparent racist attack
item.description: A statue of Modeste Testas, an African slave, has been vandalised with white paint in Bordeaux.

item.title: Daniil Medvedev: US Open champion finally celebrates - and says title is anniversary present for his wife
item.description: Winning his first Grand Slam at the US Open was enough for Daniil Medvedev to finally celebrate - and he pulled out a move from a video game.

item.title: Russia election: Opposition crushed ahead of managed polls
item.description: Exiled or disqualified, opposition voices warn of a government stitch-up in this week’s elections.

item.title: MH17: One father's testimony marked by despair and a rucksack
item.description: Relatives reveal the pain of securing justice for those who died when the flight was brought down.

item.title: 'I'll be at front of queue to change my slave name'
item.description: Descendants of African slaves welcome a Dutch city's decision to scrap fees for changing names.

item.title: Who rescues migrants in the Channel?
item.description: The number of migrants crossing the English Channel is increasing, but who is responsible for them?

item.title: Paris attacks: Historic day of reckoning for night of terror
item.description: Survivors and families attend the long-awaited trial of 20 men accused of the deadly 2015 attacks.

item.title: The 46-year-old returning to playing after drugs ban
item.description: Two bans for cocaine use seemed certain to end Francesco Flachi's career - but he is now closing in on an unlikely return at the age of 46.

item.title: Sebastian Vettel on speaking out as an LGBTQ+ ally: 'Everyone has the same right to love'
item.description: Sebastian Vettel made headlines at the Hungarian Grand Prix by wearing a T-shirt in support of LGBTQ+ rights. He tells the BBC's LGBT Sport Podcast why he is taking a stand.

item.title: Feria: Rural memoirs stir longing for Spain's past
item.description: Ana Iris Simón's autobiographical book triggers a frenzied debate about the loss of village life.

item.title: MH17 plane crash: Trial hears trauma of relatives demanding justice
item.description: The Malaysian Airlines flight was downed over Ukraine in 2014, killing all 298 people on board.

item.title: Ros Atkins on... lorry driver shortages
item.description: Ros Atkins looks at why there's a lack of drivers and how it's affecting UK businesses.

item.title: Abba announce new album Voyage and virtual concerts in London
item.description: The Swedish group unveil their first new music in almost 40 years and shows in London from May 2022.

item.title: Irish society 'can begin to hope again', says Micheál Martin
item.description: The Taoiseach (Irish prime minister) announces plan to end most Covid-19 restrictions by 22 October.

item.title: Feminist Collages London: Tackling violence against women with slogan posters
item.description: A movement that started in Paris, has now spread into locations across the globe.

item.title: Greta Thunberg: 'I'll go to COP26 if it's safe and democratic'
item.description: Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg says she does not think November's COP26 summit in Glasgow will lead to "much results".
